rev.comment: rm unsourced, non-notable paragraph from 'corporate affairs and culture'
rev.diff:
Line 81: Line 81:
[[Image:Googler2-non.jpg|250 px|thumb|A [[Vehicle registration plate|license plate]] seen in the Googleplex parking lot.]]
[[Image:Googler2-non.jpg|250 px|thumb|A [[Vehicle registration plate|license plate]] seen in the Googleplex parking lot.]]
Google is particularly known for its relaxed corporate culture, reminiscent of the [[Dot-com boom]]. In January [[2007]], it was cited by ''[[Fortune Magazine]]'' as the #1 (of 100) best company to work for.<ref name="best_company">"[http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/bestcompanies/2007/full_list/ 100 Best Companies to Work For 2007]." ''[[Fortune Magazine]] (link published by [[CNN]]).'' [[January 22]], [[2007]]. Retrieved on [[January 8]], [[2007]].</ref> Google's corporate philosophy is based on many casual principles including, "You can make money without doing evil", "You can be serious without a suit," and "Work should be challenging and the challenge should be fun." A complete list of corporate fundamentals is available on Google's website.<ref>"[http://www.google.com/corporate/tenthings.html Google Corporate Philosophy]." ''Google.'' Retrieved on [[August 31]], [[2006]].</ref> Google's relaxed corporate culture can also be seen externally through their holiday variations of the [[Google logo]].
Google is particularly known for its relaxed corporate culture, reminiscent of the [[Dot-com boom]]. In January [[2007]], it was cited by ''[[Fortune Magazine]]'' as the #1 (of 100) best company to work for.<ref name="best_company">"[http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/bestcompanies/2007/full_list/ 100 Best Companies to Work For 2007]." ''[[Fortune Magazine]] (link published by [[CNN]]).'' [[January 22]], [[2007]]. Retrieved on [[January 8]], [[2007]].</ref> Google's corporate philosophy is based on many casual principles including, "You can make money without doing evil", "You can be serious without a suit," and "Work should be challenging and the challenge should be fun." A complete list of corporate fundamentals is available on Google's website.<ref>"[http://www.google.com/corporate/tenthings.html Google Corporate Philosophy]." ''Google.'' Retrieved on [[August 31]], [[2006]].</ref> Google's relaxed corporate culture can also be seen externally through their holiday variations of the [[Google logo]].
â   â
Google's hiring policy is aggressively non-discriminatory and favors ability over experience. The result is a staff that reflects the global audience the search engine serves. However, the hiring process can be quite daunting and arduous for prospective candidates.
 
Typical salaries at Google are considered to be quite low by industry standards. For example, some [[system administrator]]s earn no more than $35,000 per year – considered to be quite low for the [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] job market.<ref name="salaries">Penenberg, Adam L. "[http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,67287-2,00.html?tw=wn_story_page_next1 Why Google Is Like Wal-Mart]." ''[[Wired]].'' [[April 21]], [[2005]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref> However, Google's excellent stock performance following its [[Initial public offering|IPO]] has enabled many early employees to be competitively compensated by participation in the corporation's remarkable equity growth.<ref name="shinalj">Shinal, John. "[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2004/08/22/BUGCL8BS201.DTL Google IPO achieved its major goal: It's all about raising cash for the company and rewarding employees, early investors]." ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]].'' [[August 22]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref> In [[2005]], Google has implemented other employee incentives such as the [[Google Founders' Award]], in addition to offering higher salaries to new employees. Google's workplace amenities, culture, global popularity, and strong brand recognition have also attracted potential applicants.
Typical salaries at Google are considered to be quite low by industry standards. For example, some [[system administrator]]s earn no more than $35,000 per year – considered to be quite low for the [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] job market.<ref name="salaries">Penenberg, Adam L. "[http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,67287-2,00.html?tw=wn_story_page_next1 Why Google Is Like Wal-Mart]." ''[[Wired]].'' [[April 21]], [[2005]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref> However, Google's excellent stock performance following its [[Initial public offering|IPO]] has enabled many early employees to be competitively compensated by participation in the corporation's remarkable equity growth.<ref name="shinalj">Shinal, John. "[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2004/08/22/BUGCL8BS201.DTL Google IPO achieved its major goal: It's all about raising cash for the company and rewarding employees, early investors]." ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]].'' [[August 22]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref> In [[2005]], Google has implemented other employee incentives such as the [[Google Founders' Award]], in addition to offering higher salaries to new employees. Google's workplace amenities, culture, global popularity, and strong brand recognition have also attracted potential applicants.
